{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3664663,"name":"Sreyan Das","username":"sdas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sdas/{size}/242589_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-25T23:19:41.742Z","cooked":"

Team 2614 Mountaineer Area RoboticS (MARS) is proud to release the code and CAD for our 2025 robot, Marvin XVIII. This year, our robot underwent serious redesigns throughout the season, and we learned a lot about the value of a simplistic design for a game that demands extremely fast cycles like REEFSCAPE. We also continued to use PhotonVision, learning a lot about optimizing our vision solution for high-performance alignment this season.

Our auto-align implementation was heavily inspired by Team 3255 the SuperNURDs, and it involved only two stored poses at any given time. This was made possible with the built-in PhotonVision class for AprilTag poses on the reef. We combined this with WPILib’s built-in Transform2d function to generate scoring poses dependent on what tag we are currently looking at that are always tag-relative. Simultaneous alignment and elevator articulation allowed us to optimize our cycle times and create an experience that was best for our drive team.

For Autonomous, we decided to utilize PathPlanner’s AutoBuilder framework, and we found great success with consistent 2-piece up to a 1-piece preload autonomous play. Our maximum performance was that of a 3-piece autonomous play that could score 2 L4 and 1 L2 coral. Additionally, we utilized alignment within our autonomous plays instead of relying on preset paths to scoring positions, and found great reliability with this approach.

Our deep cage solution used the space within our robot’s frame to push the cage down through a machined hole, grabbing onto it using magnets and balancing the weight of the robot on a foot which would catch onto the floor of the cage.

Included with this release is a short handout detailing our robot’s specifications, control scheme, and some other tidbits. We really enjoyed playing REEFSCAPE this season, and we look forward to seeing you next year!

CAD

Code

Doc
